topic.title: Restriction on Specialization: Cannot Relax Constraints

body.p: A key aspect of specialization is that while you can add new element types to the base DITA types, you cannot make the content models of these new element types less restrictive than the content models of their base types. That is, if the base type "foo" has the content model "required 'A' followed by optional 'B'", you cannot define a specialization of "foo" that makes 'A' (or a specialization of 'A') optional. By the same token, because the base content model requires 'A', your specialization of "foo" must require 'A' or a specialization of 'A'. However, because 'B' is optional in the base content model, your specialization of "foo" can omit 'B' entirely.
However, you can make the specialized content models more restrictive. Thus, you could have your specialization of "foo" require both 'A' and 'B'.

The formal way to define this rule is in terms of "generalization", such that if from a document instance that uses specialized elements you generated a new instance that used the base types of each element, would that new instance always be valid against the base declarations? If the answer is "yes", then your specialization is valid. If the answer is "no" then your specialization is not valid.
